awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: State Cooperation with the International Criminal Court
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Criminal Court (ICC) was created to bring perpetrators of mass atrocities to justice. As an international court without a police force, the ICC depends on the cooperation of states to fulfill essential investigative tasks, such as providing access to sites or arresting suspects. State cooperation is the pre-condition for the achievement of the Court's mission to end impunity. However, little is known about the extent of and rationales behind state cooperation with the Court. This study examines when and why ICC member states (states that have ratified the Rome Statute) have cooperated with the Court. The project's findings will prove valuable for US policy makers and human rights advocates seeking to enhance the effectiveness of international human rights institutions as they can contribute to a culture of accountability and foster regional stability. Moreover, fast and fair trials are in the interest of the victims of grave human rights violations who often have no other recourse to justice.

The research design concentrates on Africa, a particularly important region for studying state cooperation since all current ICC cases have originated in Africa and because this prosecution focus has prompted some African countries to call for en masse withdrawal from the Court. Two forms of state cooperation are crucial. First, using a database of 350 country statements at the UN General Assembly, the research investigates how political support for and critique of the Court have developed temporally and regionally. Supportive discourse can signal to other states that the ICC is seen as a legitimate actor and is trusted by member states. Second, the research analyzes the rationales behind concrete compliance decisions through three in-depth case studies of 'critical cooperation incidents' between African countries (Kenya, Cote d'Ivoire, South Africa) and the ICC. After creating a timeline of cooperation behavior for each country, process tracing and congruence analysis based on primary and secondary sources as well as elite interviews will be used to investigate the causal pathways to compliance and non-compliance. The project advances scholarly debates on state compliance with international law by studying rhetoric as a distinct form of cooperation, by examining compliance and non-compliance factors separately, and by highlighting regional dynamics in Africa as a new explanation for compliance.

por.por_cntn:
The project sought to better understand how and why states cooperate with the International Criminal Court (ICC). As the main international institution for criminal justice, the ICC holds enormous potential for holding individuals responsible that have committed mass atrocities. Since the Court lacks a police force of its own, it relies on states and other actors to fulfill essential tasks, such as providing evidence and executing arrest warrants. Studying patterns of cooperation and non-cooperation, and analyzing the underlying incentives behind it can help us improve compliance with the Rome Statute, the Court’s founding treaty.

The project focused particularly on the behavior of African states as (non-) cooperators because an overwhelming majority of the ICC’s active investigations to date have focused on African countries, and because this focus consequently has led to increasing critique, including calls for states parties to withdraw from the Court. In addition to researching South Africa’s non-arrest of ICC suspect at-large Omar al-Bashir of Sudan, the project used NSF funding to investigate selective cooperation by the Kenyan government in the ICC case against Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta. This case stands out as a ‘least likely’ case for cooperation considering that the accused wielded significant power and resources after being elected President in 2013. Thus, the specific goal was to better understand the extent to which the Kenyan government cooperated with the ICC and why the observed behavior occurred. During the reporting period, the graduate student co-PI worked on the dissertation’s empirical chapter on Kenya’s cooperation with the ICC, including travel to Kenya for interviews with researchers and civil society representatives who are knowledgeable about the Kenyan government’s engagement with the ICC. An article version of the dissertation chapter was presented at the International Studies Association annual meeting in Baltimore in February 2017. The project helped in the completion of a doctoral dissertation, which was defended in June 2017. This dissertation will be developed into a book manuscript that will feature insights from the article on Kenya.

The analysis of the ICC’s case against Kenyatta and the government’s behavior with the Court has revealed a ‘selective’ cooperation approach where the government cooperated ‘just enough’ to uphold a veneer of cooperation without cooperating with most Court requests. This complicates conventional understandings of compliance, which view cooperation as strictly binary. Instead, this research demonstrates in detail how a state can comply and not comply at the same time by fulfilling some court requests and not others. In addition, the dissertation used content analysis of states’ rhetoric about the Court and an in-depth analysis of South Africa’s cooperation record with the Court. Both case studies demonstrate the mediating role of the African Union in shaping African countries’ support for and cooperation with the ICC. Based on these cases, the graduate student co-PI developed a categorization of four types of ‘cooperators’ based on states’ compliance with legal obligations and their voluntary support in the form of diplomacy and statements.

The project has broader normative and policy implications. From a normative perspective, the ICC’s stated goal is to end impunity for the most heinous crimes. The pursuit of justice through prosecution is regarded as a powerful deterrent for future perpetrators with their calculations to commit atrocities being affected by a potential ICC arrest warrant. However, this noble hope only becomes a reality when the Court is actually able to start and complete trials. One stated reason for the government’s partial compliance with some requests are reputation concerns. This suggests that policymakers who are interested in fostering cooperation with the ICC should emphasize that non-cooperation results in reputational losses. In addition, policymakers can create reputational incentives for other by-stander states to cooperate with the Court.

The project contributes to our knowledge on why states comply with international law and support international institutions, such as the ICC. The dissertation argues that, when making cooperation decisions, governments are influenced by both interest calculations and reputation concerns. So when the interests of the government and the ICC are not aligned, cooperation is less likely. Thus while he Kenyan government sought to bypass the ICC’s accountability mechanism, it also provided some records to the ICC to keep up the appearance of cooperation due to regional and international reputation concerns.

Together with the other research conducted for the project, the dissertation argues that scholars should distinguish among four types of cooperators, depending on the extent to which they support the Court through voluntary statements and diplomacy as well as mandatory compliance as required by the Rome Statute. The cooperation framework can be applied to other international organizations. Moreover, the research suggests that cooperation with international institutions is subject to rational concerns over avoiding accountability and strengthening regional and international reputations.
